awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Engineering colloidal assembly of nanoemulsions for material design
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER award supports experiments, modeling, and educational activities to explore new ways of synthesizing materials based on templating.  The goal is to control interactions among droplets in a nanoemulsion so that the droplets assemble into arrangements that can be used as a template to form new materials.  The forces between droplets will be modulated by adding polymers to the nanoemulsion, which will provide control over the phase behavior of the nanoemulsion and the resulting structures formed by the nanodroplets.  As a first step, a model system will be examined consisting of oil-in-water nanoemulsions containing end-adsorbing polymers that bridge droplets in ways that can be controlled by temperature.  A variety of experimental techniques, including microrheology, isothermal titration calorimetry, and neutron scattering methods, will be used to characterize nanoemulsion structures and transitions induced by the temperature-sensitive polymers.  Modeling studies will be carried out to estimate how interactions between droplets are modified by the presence of the polymers.  In addition, new microscopy techniques will be applied to probe structural dynamics of the nanoemulsion aggregates. 

Scientists and engineers continually seek new ways to form materials with highly controlled physical and chemical properties.  The development of nanoemulsion-based templates for materials synthesis will extend the range of materials that can be formed by templating.  For example, the results of this project will provide researchers a new method to develop porous materials with highly controlled internal structures.  Various synthetic chemistries will be incorporated into the nanoemulsion formation process, resulting in materials that could be useful in catalysis, pharmaceuticals, foods, and other consumer products.  The award will also support the development of a new course and textbook on formulation science and engineering, which will broaden the curriculum for undergraduate and graduate students.  In addition, a workshop will demonstrate to middle-school students how colloidal science is used in the development of familiar consumer products.  Students from under-represented groups will be recruited to the project through established programs on the UCSB campus.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Regents of the University of California

por.por_cntn:
Emulsions – immiscible droplets of one liquid in another – pervade foods, consumer products and pharmaceuticals. In the past several decades, they have also become a foundational technology for the synthesis of structured particles and materials, where the shapes of droplets and the structures they form with each other can be used to template structures in an engineered material. The key to this capability is our ability to control the formation and properties of droplets in a suspension, while simultaneously localizing material chemistry to the droplets or the surrounding liquid. However, strategies to achieve this simultaneous control to form, assemble and perform chemistry in emulsions have been almost exclusively limited to droplets with sizes of microns or larger, preventing their broad application in the realm of nanomaterial design and engineering. To fill this length scale gap, the aim of this project was to develop new chemical, processing and characterization strategies for understanding and controlling the formation and colloidal behavior of nanoemulsions.

This central goal was accomplished through research along three primary objectives. First, we sought to design and characterizer new methods for controlling the interactions between nanodroplets to facilitate their assembly into hierarchical structures. To accomplish this, we investigated the use of temperature-sensitive polymer linkers in the fluid surrounding the droplets, measured the resulting interactions between the droplets, and characterized how these interactions drive assembly of droplets under controllable conditions. A key finding of this aspect of the work was that the resulting droplet assembly can be finely tuned with controlled variations in temperature and flow, providing new handles for guiding the processing of nanoemulsion materials.

A second objective was to develop new characterization methods by which the droplet assembly process can be visualized in order to identify and quantitatively assess the physical processes guiding droplet assembly and its evolution over time. For this, we developed two new image analysis tools, texture analysis microscopy (TAM) and differential dynamic microscopy (DDM). TAM and DDM are able to quantify structural features and dynamical processes, respectively, in video microscopy data as an alternative to conventional feature finding and tracking for optically dense, low-signal images. We used these methods to identify signatures of phase separation that drive the structuring of nanoemulsion assemblies, and used this information to identify ways to program specific length scales of phase separation in nanodroplet networks.

A third objective emerged as a result of an unexpected and exciting discovery made while formulating nanoemulsions with thermosensitive polymer linkers. Specifically, when the polymer linkers are used as surfactants – small molecules that attach to the droplet surface – they enable the formation of so-called “double nanoemulsions” – nanodroplets inside nanodroplets! Such structures are highly sought after due to their ability to co-encapsulate oil- and water-soluble compounds at the same time. However, routes to form double emulsions with nanoscale dimensions have not yet been demonstrated. Our discovery therefore opens up new capabilities for formulating fluids and particles at the nanoscale. To demonstrate this, we first mapped the conditions over which oil-in-water-in-oil double nanoemulsions could be formed and stabilized using our new strategy involving polymer linker co-surfactants. We then showed how the water compartments in these double nanoemulsion droplets could be solidified using polymer gels in order to produce solid, deformable nanocapsules that contain oily cores for controlled storage and release.

Overall, our work provides new design principles, processing schemes and research tools for tailoring the structure and properties of nanoemulsions, and could impact a number of technologies spanning foods, consumer products, and biopharmaceuticals. This project also led to the training and successful degrees of three Ph.D. students and one M.S. student. The results were disseminated to the research community through 13 peer-reviewed publications, 1 recently issued patent, and dozens of lectures and presentations at scientific meetings and conferences. Software for TAM and DDM is made available to the research community on the PI’s website, and has been downloaded by more than 600 researchers worldwide. The discovery of double nanoemulsions was used to develop an educational activity with live demonstrations for K-12 outreach activities.


Last Modified: 03/14/2022
Modified by: Matthew E Helgeson
